title: Tara Slone
text:
Tara Kamala Slone (born September 7, 1973) is a <a href="Canadians">Canadian</a> <a href="rock%20music">rock</a> vocalist, actress and television personality.
Early life and education.
Slone was born in <a href="Montreal">Montreal</a>, <a href="Quebec">Quebec</a>, and raised in <a href="Wolfville%2C%20Nova%20Scotia">Wolfville</a> and <a href="Halifax%2C%20Nova%20Scotia">Halifax</a>, <a href="Nova%20Scotia">Nova Scotia</a>. Her stepfather Dr. Tomacz Pietrzykowski was the Dean of the School of Computer Science at <a href="Acadia%20University">Acadia University</a>. She began pursuing classical voice training at the age of 12 with the goal of becoming an <a href="opera">opera</a> singer. Her first job was at a <a href="Second%20Cup">Second Cup</a> in Halifax when she was in high school as a <a href="barista">barista</a> for a few months before working at <a href="Sam%20the%20Record%20Man">Sam the Record Man</a>. She connected with music lovers and indie musicians, which she credits as influencing her taste in music. 
At the age of 18, she attended <a href="Concordia%20University%20%28Quebec%29">Concordia University</a> to pursue a degree in music. While there, she switched her aspirations to acting and rock music, and subsequently moved to <a href="Toronto">Toronto</a>.
Theatre career.
In the mid-1990s, Slone played Columbia in the <a href="Rocky%20Horror%20Show">Rocky Horror Show</a> in front of sold-out crowds when it stopped at the Grand Theatre in <a href="Kingston%2C%20Ontario">Kingston, Ontario</a>.
In 2016, Slone appeared on stage at the <a href="Stratford%20Festival">Stratford Festival</a> in the play <a href="The%20Hypochondriac%20%28play%29">The Hypochondriac</a>.
Music career.
In 1996, Slone became the lead singer of <a href="Joydrop">Joydrop</a>. The band released two albums, had chart hits in Canada with "<a href="Beautiful%20%28Joydrop%20song%29">Beautiful</a>" and "Sometimes Wanna Die," and was nominated for a <a href="Juno%20Award">Juno Award</a>.
In 1998, Slone landed a recurring role in "<a href="La%20Femme%20Nikita%20%28TV%20series%29">La Femme Nikita</a>". She appeared in three episodes. In 2008, she appeared in an episode of the second season of "<a href="The%20Border%20%28TV%20series%29">The Border</a>", titled "Prescriptive Measures", as an American pop star who dies early on in the episode, which sparks the main plot of the episode.
Since the breakup of Joydrop, Slone has worked on a solo album with <a href="Jordon%20Zadorozny">Jordon Zadorozny</a>. Her latest album is "Just Look Pretty and Sing", which was released on March 6, 2007. Singles released include "My Little Secret", "We Were Stars" and "The Perfect Girl." Joydrop reunited on April 2, 2017, edition of Hometown Hockey in Guelph, Ontario with Slone performing "Beautiful".
Slone competed on "<a href="Rock%20Star%20INXS">Rock Star INXS</a>". On week four, she was again placed in the bottom three after her version of "<a href="Message%20in%20a%20Bottle%20%28The%20Police%20song%29">Message in a Bottle</a>". She was then eliminated that week.
Slone is currently signed to <a href="Orange%20Record%20Label">Orange Record Label</a>.
She previously resided in Toronto, sharing a house with fellow "Rock Star INXS" contestant <a href="Suzie%20McNeil">Suzie McNeil</a>. The two appeared in an episode of "<a href="MTV%20Cribs">MTV Cribs</a>", giving viewers a tour of their house.
Broadcasting career.
From August 9, 2010 to August 28, 2015, Slone served as the host of "<a href="Breakfast%20Television">Breakfast Television</a>" on <a href="CKAL-DT">Citytv Calgary</a>.
In 2014, Slone joined <a href="Sportsnet">Sportsnet</a>, acting as an on-site co-host for its new Sunday-night "<a href="NHL%20on%20Sportsnet">Rogers Hometown Hockey</a>" broadcasts alongside <a href="Ron%20MacLean">Ron MacLean</a>.
In 2020, Slone was named host of a new weekly Sportsnet <a href="docuseries">docuseries</a> called "<a href="Top%20of%20Her%20Game">Top of Her Game</a>", which focuses on <a href="women%27s%20rights">women's rights</a> through interviews with female athletes, builders and executives. In the same year she was host of the summer concert series "<a href="Budweiser%20Stage%20at%20Home">Budweiser Stage at Home</a>" for the <a href="Citytv">Citytv</a> network, for which she received a <a href="Canadian%20Screen%20Award">Canadian Screen Award</a> nomination for Best Host in a Talk Show or Entertainment News Series at the <a href="9th%20Canadian%20Screen%20Awards">9th Canadian Screen Awards</a>.
Personal life.
She is married and has a daughter.
Accolades.
- 2002 Best New Group (<a href="2002%20Juno%20Awards">Juno Awards</a> - Nominee)<br>
- 2012 Best Television Host (Alberta Film & Television Awards - Finalist)<br>
- 2013 Best Television Host (Alberta Film & Television Awards - Winner)
